title: Los Angeles Motor Scale (LAMS)
description: Stratifies stroke severity in the field to identify patients with large vessel occlusion

parameters.name: facial_droop
parameters.description: Presence and severity of facial droop or weakness

parameters.name: arm_drift
parameters.description: Arm drift or fall when arms held extended for 10 seconds

result.name: lams_score
result.description: Los Angeles Motor Scale score (0-5 points)

ranges.interpretation: LVO less likely. Stroke is minor or moderate in severity, but may still benefit from acute treatment. Consider transport to nearest stroke-capable facility.
LVO likely. Stroke is severe and requires acute treatment. Transfer to stroke center with endovascular capabilities for possible mechanical thrombectomy.

references: Llanes JN, Kidwell CS, Starkman S, Leary MC, Eckstein M, Saver JL. The Los Angeles Motor Scale (LAMS): a new measure to characterize stroke severity in the field. Prehosp Emerg Care. 2004 Jan-Mar;8(1):46-50. doi: 10.1080/312703002806.

Nazliel B, Starkman S, Liebeskind DS, Ovbiagele B, Kim D, Sanossian N, et al. A brief prehospital stroke severity scale identifies ischemic stroke patients harboring persisting large arterial occlusions. Stroke. 2008 Aug;39(8):2264-7. doi: 10.1161/STROKEAHA.107.508127.

Pérez de la Ossa N, Carrera D, Gorchs M, Querol M, Millán M, Gomis M, et al. Design and validation of a prehospital stroke scale to predict large arterial occlusion: the rapid arterial occlusion evaluation scale. Stroke. 2014 Jan;45(1):87-91. doi: 10.1161/STROKEAHA.113.003071.
formula: LAMS score = Facial droop (0-1) + Arm drift (0-2) + Grip strength (0-2). Score ≥4 suggests large vessel occlusion (LVO) requiring endovascular intervention.
notes: Designed for prehospital assessment by emergency medical services (EMS)
Sensitivity of 81% and specificity of 89% for predicting large vessel occlusion
Score ≥4 increases by 7-fold the likelihood of persisting large vessel occlusion
Should be used for field triage to guide transport destination
Not a substitute for comprehensive neurologic examination or full NIHSS
Helps identify patients who may benefit from direct transport to comprehensive stroke centers
Time-sensitive assessment - should be completed rapidly in the field
Validated for use by paramedics and emergency medical technicians
Originally derived from Los Angeles Prehospital Stroke Screen (LAPSS) motor components
